texts.label: text
texts.orig: One of my favorite (and most used) applications on any Linux machine is  screen . Once you fire up a screen session, you can start something and keep it running indefinitely. Even if your internet connection drops or you accidentally close your terminal window, the screen session will remain open on the remote server.
texts.text: One of my favorite (and most used) applications on any Linux machine is  screen . Once you fire up a screen session, you can start something and keep it running indefinitely. Even if your internet connection drops or you accidentally close your terminal window, the screen session will remain open on the remote server.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Detaching from a screen session is done by pressing CTRL-A and then d (for detach). However, when I'm on my Mac, CTRL-A and CTRL-E send my cursor to the beginning and end of lines, respectively. Once I launch screen, I lose the CTRL-A functionality because screen thinks I'm trying to send it a command.
texts.text: Detaching from a screen session is done by pressing CTRL-A and then d (for detach). However, when I'm on my Mac, CTRL-A and CTRL-E send my cursor to the beginning and end of lines, respectively. Once I launch screen, I lose the CTRL-A functionality because screen thinks I'm trying to send it a command.
